fields.physical_description: A Dutch army trumpeter blows his horn while the men and women around him, seemingly oblivious, continue to go about their business, dressing, smoking and warming themselves by the fire
fields.dimensions: Height: 36.7 cm, Width: 48 cm, Height: 472 mm frame, Width: 590 mm frame, Depth: 64 mm frame
fields.title: The Trumpeter
fields.public_access_description: A Dutch army trumpeter blows his horn while the men and women around him, seemingly oblivious, continue to go about their business, dressing, smoking and warming themselves by the fire.  Anthonie [Stevers] Palamedes, (b Delft, 1601; d Amsterdam, 1673) was a Dutch painter. His teacher is unknown, but he may have studied in Delft with the court painter Michiel van Mierevelt and/or Hendrik Pot, who was in the city in 1620. Palamedes joined the Delft Guild of St Luke in 1621. In 1673 Anthonie was residing in Amsterdam, probably with his eldest son, the painter Palamedes Palamedes II.  Anthonie was a genre, portrait and still-life painter but is best known for his paintings depicting musical or merry companies and soldiers. Such works attest to his knowledge of contemporary genre paintings by Haarlem and Amsterdam artists, such as Dirck Hals, Pieter Codde, Willem Duyster and Hendrik Pot. In the 1640s and 1650s Palamedesz. often painted guardroom scenes and soldiers with their camp followers in stables, adopting compositions recalling designs by Duyster and Jacob Duck but executed in a looser, less refined technique. Palamedes painted several different composition depicting a trumpeter with a clarion flag hung from his instrument. The trumpeter's task in the Dutch army was to alert all the soldiers in the guardroom (cortegaard) to march out of the military unit following a commander's orders.
fields.bibliography: Kauffmann, C.M. Catalogue of Foreign Paintings, I. Before 1800. London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 1973, p. 211, cat. no. 265 The following is the full text of the entry: Anthonie PALAMEDES (1601-73) Dutch School A pupil of Michiel van Miereveld, he is best-known for his genre pictures and portraits. In 1621 he joined the painters' guild in Delft. One of his pupils was his brother, the battle-painter, Palamedes Palamedesz. (1607-38). 265 THE TRUMPETER Signed lower left A. Palamedes, 1654 Oak panel 14 ¼ X 19 (36.7 X 48) Townshend Bequest 1350-1869 As was his custom, Palamedes repeated this composition, with variations in the figures and the setting, numerous times (for example, Hoech collection sale, Munich, 19 Sept. 1892, lot 161, dated 1653; Lathom sale, Christie's, 11 June 1926, lot 79, dated 1656; Guggenheim sale, Parke-Bernet, New York, 31 Jan.-3 Feb. 1945, lot 501, dated 1665; Hôtel Drouot sale, 29 May 1967, lot 119.) All of these have the standing trumpeter, but differ from 1350-1869 in showing him more or less frontally, his head facing right, holding the trumpet with his left hand. A similar composition showing the trumpeter seated is in the National Museum, Warsaw. Condition. Cleaned in 1960, when the signature reappeared. The panel seems to have been slightly cut down on the sides. Prov. Seen by Waagen in the Rev. C. H. Townshend's library in 1854 or '56; bequeathed to the Museum in 1868. Lit. Waagen, Supplement, 1857, p. 180. Waagen, Galleries and Cabinets of Art in Great Britain: Being an account of more than forty collections of Paintings, Drawings, Sculptures, Mss, etc, London, 1857, p.180. The following is the full text of the catalogue entry: "PALAMEDES PALAMEDES.- A courtyard with many figures, among which a trumpeter in the act of blowing his instrument, and a woman with a child on her arm, are conspicuous. For picturesque composition and careful carrying out, this is a good specimen of the painter. Gustav Waagen" Masters of Seventeenth-century Dutch Genre Painting (exh. cat. by P. C. Sutton, Philadelphia, PA, Mus. A.; Berlin, Gemäldegal.; London, RA; 1984), pp. 292–3 General Ref. Painting not mentioned or loaned to exhibition
fields.credit: Bequeathed by Rev., Chauncey Hare Townshend
fields.history_note: Bequeathed by Rev. Chauncey Hare Townshend, 1868 Historical significance: Anthonie [Stevers] Palamedes, (b Delft, 1601; d Amsterdam, 1673) was a Dutch painter. His teacher is unknown, but he may have studied in Delft with the court painter Michiel van Mierevelt and/or Hendrik Pot, who was in the city in 1620. Palamedes joined the Delft Guild of St Luke in 1621. In 1673 Anthonie was residing in Amsterdam, probably with his eldest son, the painter Palamedes Palamedes II. Anthonie was a genre, portrait and still-life painter but is best known for his paintings depicting musical or merry companies and soldiers. Such works attest to his knowledge of contemporary genre paintings by Haarlem and Amsterdam artists, such as Dirck Hals, Pieter Codde, Willem Duyster and Hendrik Pot. In the 1640s and 1650s Palamedesz. often painted guardroom scenes and soldiers with their camp followers in stables, adopting compositions recalling designs by Duyster and Jacob Duck but executed in a looser, less refined technique. Palamedes painted several different composition depicting a trumpeter with a clarion flag hung from his instrument. The trumpeter's task in the Dutch army was to alert all the soldiers in the guardroom (cortegaard) to march out of the military unit following a commander's orders.
fields.historical_context_note: Genre paintings such as this often represented the lower classes of society, especially peasants, but as the decades progressed such pictures evolved to included more elevated classes and became especially popular in Holland in the the 17th century. These pictures often depict scenes of everyday life set in domestic interiors or in the countryside. Scholars continue to debate whether they bear a metaphorical meaning and hidden messages, or just feature a close depiction of contemporary events. In both case they are associated with health, pleasure and liberty.
